mnemonic_verse:
We overbuild when facts are thin,
Add belt and brace and call it win;
But surplus steel and wider frames,
Lock waste in walls and raise the claims.
description: Caution with reclaimed components often leads to over-engineering. While this ensures safety, it drives inefficient material use, adding cost and undermining resource conservation goals.
source: Building Confidence — June 2025 — Circular Buildings Coalition

mnemonic_verse:
A beam once strong now trims a door,
Each step down value, less than before;
When grade drops low to make reuse fit,
We save the part but squander its wit.
description: Cascading reclaimed products into lower-value uses secures reuse but squanders much of their potential. This reduces efficiency compared to retaining them in equivalent-grade applications.
source: Building Confidence — June 2025 — Circular Buildings Coalition

mnemonic_verse:
If every brick must tell its tale,
With scans and logs that seldom scale;
The proof we seek inflates the price,
And stalls the will to reuse twice.
description: High demands for traceability and performance proof reduce uncertainty but add significant cost and delay. This discourages adoption until better data systems mature.
source: Building Confidence — June 2025 — Circular Buildings Coalition

mnemonic_verse:
A smokestack speaks of carbon cost,
Each ton we burn, more futures lost;
Efficiency first, then capture the rest,
To keep the climate at its best.
description: Carbon emissions from construction remain a central threat. Prioritizing efficiency, low-carbon materials, and targeted carbon capture is key to aligning with climate goals.
source: Four Circular Building Pathways — April 2024 — Circular Buildings Coalition

mnemonic_verse:
Walls of wood grow back again,
Unlike the stone or steel of men;
Biobased beams, if managed right,
Can store the carbon out of sight.
description: Biobased materials such as timber offer renewable, carbon-storing alternatives to concrete or steel. Their climate benefit depends on sustainable forestry and careful life-cycle planning.
source: Pathways to Biobased Construction — March 2023 — World Green Building Council

mnemonic_verse:
Regulators set the tightening bar,
Thresholds climb both near and far;
Tomorrow’s law will shape today,
To build with less in every way.
description: EU and city-level regulations are steadily introducing whole-life carbon thresholds and circularity criteria. These standards will drive rapid demand for secondary and low-carbon materials.
source: EPBD Recast Report — January 2025 — European Commission

mnemonic_verse:
Insurance hides behind the veil,
Of rules for new that sometimes fail;
But risk re-framed and trust aligned,
Can open markets left behind.
description: Insurance frameworks designed for new materials often exclude reused ones, creating uncertainty. Clearer underwriting, data, and tailored guarantees are essential to unlock reuse at scale.
source: Building Confidence — June 2025 — Circular Buildings Coalition

mnemonic_verse:
A healthy home is more than walls,
It filters air and light that calls;
Design with people at the heart,
To heal the body from the start.
description: Health outcomes in buildings extend beyond carbon. Attention to indoor air, natural light, and low-toxin materials creates environments that support wellbeing alongside sustainability.
source: Healthy Buildings Report — September 2022 — Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health

mnemonic_verse:
Supply chains stretch and sometimes break,
A fragile link is all it takes;
Local reuse and mapped demand,
Can steady flows across the land.
description: Construction supply chains remain fragile, especially for reused materials. Better visibility, forecasting, and localized harvesting strategies reduce risk and stabilize availability.
source: Resilient Supply Chains in Construction — July 2024 — Arup

mnemonic_verse:
Digital twins can show the past,
A building’s data built to last;
Passports track from birth to end,
So trust in reuse can ascend.
description: Material passports and digital building records are critical enablers of circularity. They preserve provenance and performance data, allowing secondary products to be specified with confidence.
source: Material Passports for Circular Economy — May 2023 — Ellen MacArthur Foundation
